newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's Birch says no optimum savings rate set.
newsitem.headline: NZ's Birch says no optimum savings rate set.

text.p: The New Zealand government had not determined the ideal rate of savings it would like to see, Finance Minister Bill Birch said on Monday.
"The ideal is as high as you can get it. But we have not addressed an optimum level of savings," he said, in answer to questions after a speech to the SBC Warburg Investor Group.

The coalition government will hold a referendum in September on the introduction of compulsory retirement savings. A group of officials are designing the scheme which, if approved, would be implemented in July 1998.
The coalition agreement between the conservative National Party and the nationalist New Zealand First aimed to increase New Zealand's national savings rate.
The most recent statistics available show household savings were 5.2 percent of disposable income in 1995.

Asked to explain New Zealand's low level of savings, Birch said it was partly due to the way it was measured (with New Zealanders having a high level of home ownership) and partly due to the environment.
"Public provision of retirement income may be sending the wrong signals and that is something we should look at as we develop the referendum," Birch said.
"What I am totally convinced of is that offering tax incentives is not a good way to encourage savings."

He said the high level of overseas ownership of government debt issues was a vote of confidence by international investors and also reflected New Zealanders' willingness to invest offshore. -- Wellington newsroom 64 4 473 4746
